articles.headline: Coal Jobs Prove Lucrative, but Not for Those in the Mines
articles.snippet: The already large wage gap between the coal industry’s top executives and average coal workers is expanding further.
articles.abstract: The already large wage gap between the coal industry’s top executives and average coal workers is expanding further.
articles.lead_paragraph: Glenn Kellow, the coal executive who led Peabody Energy through bankruptcy, just collected an estimated $15 million stock bonus. John Eaves at Arch Coal, another recently bankrupt coal giant, got an award valued at $10 million.

articles.headline: Officers Won’t Be Charged in Black Man’s Shooting Death in Louisiana
articles.snippet: The shooting death of Alton B. Sterling by white police officers raised an outcry and prompted a Justice Department inquiry, fueling a national debate about race and justice.
articles.abstract: The shooting death of Alton B. Sterling by white police officers raised an outcry and prompted a Justice Department inquiry, fueling a national debate about race and justice.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Two white police officers will not face federal charges in the fatal shooting of a black man last year in Baton Rouge, La., which caused widespread unrest there. The decision was made with the Trump administration under scrutiny about how it will handle prosecutions in racially charged police shootings, a priority of the Obama administration.

articles.headline: Political Turmoil Is High, but Wall Street’s Fear Gauge Is Very Low
articles.snippet: Since President Trump was elected, as political risks have increased at home and abroad, complacency among investors has rarely been so widespread.
articles.abstract: Since President Trump was elected, as political risks have increased at home and abroad, complacency among investors has rarely been so widespread.
articles.lead_paragraph: It has become one of the knottier puzzles on Wall Street.

articles.headline: U.S. Auto Boom Seems to Be History, Just as Trump Counted on Jobs
articles.snippet: A fourth straight monthly sales decline, at a rate exceeding forecasts, put a dent in automakers’ shares. “The market is tapped out,” a dealer said.
articles.abstract: A fourth straight monthly sales decline, at a rate exceeding forecasts, put a dent in automakers’ shares. “The market is tapped out,” a dealer said.
articles.lead_paragraph: For seven years, the steadily expanding auto industry has helped drive the American economy forward, racking up billions in profit and paying workers hefty bonuses, all while consumers flocked to dealerships and drove sales to record heights.

articles.headline: James Comey ‘Mildly Nauseous’ Over Idea He Swayed the Election
articles.snippet: The F.B.I. director spoke publicly for the first time about his decisions about the Hillary Clinton email inquiry in the days before the election.
articles.abstract: The F.B.I. director spoke publicly for the first time about his decisions about the Hillary Clinton email inquiry in the days before the election.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — James B. Comey, the F.B.I. director, sharply defended his decision to notify Congress about new emails in the Hillary Clinton investigation just before Election Day, reopening on Wednesday the still-raw debate over whether he cost her the presidency.

articles.headline: Giving the Behemoths a Leg Up on the Little Guy
articles.snippet: The new F.C.C. chairman’s plan to slacken net neutrality rules is a boon to tech giants and a bane to competitors and innovators.
articles.abstract: The new F.C.C. chairman’s plan to slacken net neutrality rules is a boon to tech giants and a bane to competitors and innovators.
articles.lead_paragraph: Every year, the internet gets a little less fair. The corporations that run it get a little bigger, their power grows more concentrated, and a bit of their idealism gives way to ruthless pragmatism.

articles.headline: Georgia Wonders: Will Newcomers Dye the Suburbs Blue?
articles.snippet: The white-flight suburb of Johns Creek, out of reach of Atlanta’s transit system, is now rippling with diversity and facing a possible watershed election.
articles.abstract: The white-flight suburb of Johns Creek, out of reach of Atlanta’s transit system, is now rippling with diversity and facing a possible watershed election.
articles.lead_paragraph: JOHNS CREEK, Ga. — At first blush, this bedroom city of 83,000 a half-hour north of Atlanta might be mistaken for the perfect example of a white-flight Sun Belt suburb.

articles.headline: Marine Le Pen, a Fierce Campaigner, Heads to Finale in French Election
articles.snippet: A far-right populist who has threatened to bring down the European Union, Ms. Le Pen is at the threshold of power as France prepares for the final round of voting.
articles.abstract: A far-right populist who has threatened to bring down the European Union, Ms. Le Pen is at the threshold of power as France prepares for the final round of voting.
articles.lead_paragraph: NICE, France — The lights dimmed and the music steadily built. Ravel’s “Bolero,” at once martial and sensual, wrapped the crowd in its sinister embrace, the atmosphere laced with menace. The audience murmured in the dark, expectant, awaiting deliverance.

articles.headline: With $8 Billion Deal on Health Bill, House G.O.P. Leader Says ‘We Have Enough Votes’
articles.snippet: A vote was scheduled for Thursday, and the majority leader sounded confident about its chances, as critics called the added funding inadequate.
articles.abstract: A vote was scheduled for Thursday, and the majority leader sounded confident about its chances, as critics called the added funding inadequate.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — House Republican leaders planned to hold a showdown vote Thursday on their bill to repeal and replace large portions of the Affordable Care Act after adding $8 billion to the measure to help cover insurance costs for people with pre-existing conditions.
articles.byline: By Thomas Kaplan and Robert Pear

articles.headline: Puerto Rico Declares a Form of Bankruptcy
articles.snippet: The island’s governor said he would move its debt crisis into federal court, making it the largest United States government entity to seek refuge from creditors in American history.
articles.abstract: The island’s governor said he would move its debt crisis into federal court, making it the largest United States government entity to seek refuge from creditors in American history.
articles.lead_paragraph: With its creditors at its heels and its coffers depleted, Puerto Rico sought what is essentially bankruptcy relief in federal court on Wednesday, the first time in history that an American state or territory had taken the extraordinary measure.

articles.headline: Facebook Scrambles to Police Content Amid Rapid Growth
articles.snippet: Mark Zuckerberg, the company’s chief executive, said he would hire 3,000 more people to monitor posts and live video as the site nears 2 billion users.
articles.abstract: Mark Zuckerberg, the company’s chief executive, said he would hire 3,000 more people to monitor posts and live video as the site nears 2 billion users.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — As a business, Facebook is more successful than ever. On Wednesday afternoon, it reported another quarter of huge growth, with nearly 2 billion people actively using the service and revenue up 49 percent in the first quarter compared with a year ago.
